paragraph: CHAPTER XXII. THE OLD LADY AND CURDIE
tokens: old lady

paragraph: UP the stair then they went, and the next and the next, and through the long rows of empty rooms, and up the little tower stairs, Irene growing happier and happier as she ascended. There was no answer when she knocked at length at the door of the workroom, nor could she hear any sound of the spinning-wheel, and once more her heart sank within her--but only for one moment, as she turned and knocked at the other door.

paragraph: "You darling!" cried the lady, who was seated by a fire of red roses mingled with white--"I've been waiting for you, and indeed getting a little anxious about you, and beginning to think whether I had not better go and fetch you myself."

paragraph: "People must believe what they can, and those who believe more must not be hard upon those who believe less. I doubt if you would have believed it all yourself if you hadn't seen some of it."

paragraph: "No I don't," answered Curdie, almost sulkily.

paragraph: "Nor the blue bed? Nor the rose-colored counterpane? Nor the beautiful light, like the moon, hanging from the roof?"

paragraph: "You're making game of me, your royal Highness; and after what we have come through together this day, I don't think it is kind of you," said Curdie, feeling very much hurt.

paragraph: "I see a tub, and a heap of musty straw, and a withered apple and a ray of sunlight coming through a hole in the middle of the roof, and shining on your head, and making all the place look a curious dusky brown. I think you had better drop it, princess, and go down to the nursery, like a good girl."

paragraph: "But don't you hear my grandmother talking to me?" asked Irene, almost crying.

paragraph: "No. I hear the cooing of a lot of pigeons. If you won't come down, I will go without you. I think that will be better anyhow, for I'm sure nobody who met us would believe a word we said to them. They would think we made it all up. I don't expect anybody but my own father and mother to believe me. They _know_ I wouldn't tell a story."

paragraph: "No. I _can't_, and I can't help it," said Curdie, turning to leave the room.

paragraph: "You must give him time," said her grandmother; "and you must be content not to be believed for a while. It is very hard to bear; but I have had to bear it, and shall have to bear it many a time yet. I will take care of what Curdie thinks of you in the end. You must let him go now."

paragraph: "You are not coming, are you?" asked Curdie.

paragraph: "No, Curdie; my grandmother says I must let you go. Turn to the right when you get to the bottom of all the stairs, and in that way you will arrive safely at the hall where the great door is."

paragraph: "Oh! I don't doubt I can find my way--without you, princess, or your old grannie's thread either," said Curdie, quite rudely.

paragraph: "Oh, Curdie! Curdie!"
"I wish I had gone home at once. I'm very much obliged to you, Irene, for getting me out of that hole, but I wish you hadn't made a fool of me afterward."

paragraph: He said this as he opened the door, which he left open, and, without another word, went down the stairs. Irene listened with dismay to his departing footsteps. Then turning again to the lady--
tokens: say open door leave open word go stair listen dismay depart footstep turn lady

paragraph: "What does it all mean, grandmother?" she sobbed, and burst into fresh tears.

paragraph: "It means, my love, that I did not mean to show myself. Curdie is not yet able to believe some things. Seeing is not believing--it is only seeing. You remember I told you that if Lootie were to see me, she would rub her eyes, forget the half she saw, and call the other half nonsense."
tokens: mean love mean show able believe thing see believe see remember tell see rub eye forget half see call other half nonsense

paragraph: "Yes; but I should have thought Curdie--"
tokens: think

paragraph: "You are right. Curdie is much farther on than Lootie, and you will see what will come of it. But in the meantime, you must be content, I say, to be misunderstood for a while. We are all very anxious to be understood, and it is very hard not to be. But there is one thing much more necessary."

paragraph: "What is that, grandmother?"

paragraph: "To understand other people."

paragraph: "Yes, grandmother. I must be fair--for if I'm not fair to other people, I'm not worth being understood myself I see. So as Curdie can't help it, I will not be vexed with him, but just wait."

paragraph: "There's my own dear child," said her grandmother, and pressed her close to her bosom.

paragraph: "Why weren't you in your workroom, when we came up, grandmother?" asked Irene, after a few moments' silence.

paragraph: "If I had been there, Curdie would have seen me well enough. But why should I be there rather than in this beautiful room?"

paragraph: "I thought you would be spinning."

paragraph: "I've nobody to spin for just at present. I never spin without knowing for whom I am spinning."

paragraph: "That reminds me--there is one thing that puzzles me," said the princess: "how are you to get the thread out of the mountain again? Surely you won't have to make another for me! That would be such a trouble!"

paragraph: The lady set her down, and rose, and went to the fire. Putting in her hand, she drew it out again, and held up the shining ball between her finger and thumb.

paragraph: "Oh, thank you, grandmother. I feel so safe now!"

paragraph: "You are very tired, my child," the lady went on. "Your hands are hurt with the stones, and I have counted nine bruises on you. Just look what you are like."
tokens: tired child lady go hand hurt stone count bruise look

paragraph: And she held up to her a little mirror which she had brought from the cabinet. The princess burst into a merry laugh at the sight. She was so draggled with the stream, and dirty with creeping through narrow places, that if she had seen the reflection without knowing it was a reflection, she would have taken herself for some gypsy-child whose face was washed and hair combed about once in a month. The lady laughed too, and lifting her again upon her knee, took off her cloak and night-gown. Then she carried her to the side of the room. Irene wondered what she was going to do with her, but asked no questions--only starting a little when she found that she was going to lay her in the large silver bath; for as she looked into it, again she saw no bottom, but the stars shining miles away as it seemed in a great blue gulf. Her hands closed involuntarily on the beautiful arms that held her, and that was all.
tokens: hold little mirror bring cabinet princess burst merry laugh sight draggle stream dirty creep narrow place see reflection know reflection take gypsy child face wash hair comb month lady laugh lift knee take cloak night gown carry side room wonder go do ask question start little find go lay large silver bath look see bottom star shine mile seem great blue gulf hand close beautiful arm hold

paragraph: The lady pressed her once more to her bosom, saying--
tokens: lady press more bosom say

paragraph: "Do not be afraid, my child."
tokens: afraid child

paragraph: "No, grandmother," answered the princess, with a little gasp; and the next instant she sank in the clear cool water.
tokens: grandmother answer princess little gasp next instant sink clear cool water

paragraph: When she opened her eyes, she saw nothing but a strange lovely blue over and beneath and all about her. The lady and the beautiful room had vanished from her sight, and she seemed utterly alone. But instead of being afraid, she felt more than happy--perfectly blissful. And from somewhere came the voice of the lady, singing a strange sweet song, of which she could distinguish every word; but of the sense she had only a feeling--no understanding. Nor could she remember a single line after it was gone. It vanished, like the poetry in a dream, as fast as it came. In after years, however, she would sometimes fancy that snatches of melody suddenly rising in her brain, must be little phrases and fragments of the air of that song; and the very fancy would make her happier, and abler to do her duty.
tokens: open eye see strange lovely blue lady beautiful room vanish sight seem alone afraid feel more happy blissful come voice lady sing strange sweet song distinguish word sense have feeling understanding remember single line gone vanish poetry dream come year fancy snatch melody rise brain little phrase fragment air song very fancy make happy abler do duty

paragraph: How long she lay in the water she did not know. It seemed a long time--not from weariness, but from pleasure. But at last she felt the beautiful hands lay hold of her, and through the gurgling waters she was lifted out into the lovely room. The lady carried her to the fire, and sat down with her in her lap, and dried her tenderly with the softest towel. It was so different from Lootie's drying! When the lady had done, she stooped to the fire, and drew from it her night-gown, as white as snow.
tokens: lay water know seem long time weariness pleasure last feel beautiful hand lay hold gurgle water lift lovely room lady carry fire sit lap dry softest towel different drying lady do stoop fire draw night gown white snow

paragraph: "How delicious!" exclaimed the princess. "It smells of all the roses in the world, I think."
tokens: delicious exclaim princess smell rose world think

paragraph: When she stood up on the floor, she felt as if she had been made over again. Every bruise and all weariness were gone, and her hands were soft and whole as ever.
tokens: stand floor feel make bruise weariness gone hand soft whole

tokens: think say ask

paragraph: "Don't trouble yourself about it. You will find it all come right," said her grandmother, and laid her into the blue bed, under the rosy counterpane.
tokens: trouble find come say grandmother lay blue bed rosy counterpane

paragraph: "I took care of all that," answered the lady. "I told you to let him go, and therefore I was bound to look after him. Nobody saw him, and he is now eating a good dinner in his mother's cottage, far up the mountain."
